questions.guidance_text: Enter your company's legal name as registered with ROC or shown on GST certificate. This name will appear on the open cover policy which provides blanket coverage for all your cargo shipments throughout the policy period.

Provide your company's registered office address where official correspondence will be sent. Include building name/number, street, area, city, state and pincode. This address will be used for policy documentation and claims communication.
questions.placeholder: e.g., 501, Trade Center, Nariman Point, Mumbai, Maharashtra - 400021

questions.guidance_text: Enter the primary mobile number for urgent communications regarding shipments and claims. This number should be accessible during business hours for immediate claim intimation which is crucial for marine cargo claims.

Provide your business email for receiving policy documents, shipment declarations, and claim forms. Ensure this email is regularly monitored as marine claims require prompt action and documentation submission.

Describe all types of goods you regularly ship that need coverage under this open policy. Be specific about product categories, materials, and whether they include hazardous, fragile, or temperature-sensitive items. Different cargo types may have different premium rates.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Electronic components, Computer peripherals, Mobile phone accessories, LED displays - all new goods, non-hazardous

questions.guidance_text: Select all packing methods you use for shipments. Proper packing reduces damage risk and claims. Standard export-quality packing typically gets better rates than loose cargo. Marine insurers assess packing quality as a key risk factor.

Select all transportation modes you use. Open cover policies can include multiple modes. Sea freight typically has different rates than air freight. Multimodal shipments need end-to-end coverage across all transport legs.

List your common shipping routes including origin and destination countries/cities. Include both import and export routes. Routes through high-risk areas or war zones may need additional coverage. This helps determine geographic scope of coverage.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Mumbai to New York (USA), Chennai to Singapore, Delhi to Dubai (UAE), Shanghai (China) to Mumbai

questions.guidance_text: Select the duration for your open cover policy. Annual policies are most common for regular shippers. The policy automatically covers all shipments during this period once you declare them, eliminating the need for individual transit policies.
Choose when the open cover should begin. Ensure there's no gap from your current marine policy expiry. All shipments from this date will be automatically covered upon declaration to the insurer.

ICC (A) provides widest 'All Risks' coverage including theft, non-delivery, and damage. ICC (B) covers specific named perils. ICC (C) offers basic coverage for major perils only. Most exporters/importers prefer ICC (A) for comprehensive protection.

War covers damage from war, terrorism, and similar perils. SRCC (Strikes, Riots, Civil Commotion) covers losses from labor unrest and civil disturbances. These are important for shipments through volatile regions or during uncertain times.

Enter your total annual import/export turnover including customs duties and taxes. This helps determine your cargo movement volume and appropriate sum insured limits. The premium is typically calculated as a percentage of this turnover.

Enter the total value of goods you expect to ship in the policy year. This includes both imports and exports at invoice value. This amount determines your deposit premium and helps set appropriate per-shipment limits.

Enter the maximum value of any single shipment you might send. Open covers have per-shipment limits. Shipments exceeding this limit need prior insurer approval. Set this considering your largest typical consignment value plus 10% margin.

Standard marine practice is to insure cargo at CIF (Cost, Insurance, Freight) plus 10-15% to cover additional expenses and profit margin. Higher percentage provides better claim settlement but increases premium. CIF+10% is most common.

Declare any marine cargo claims in the past 5 years. Transparency is essential as insurers share claims data. Previous claims help insurers assess risk patterns and may lead to risk improvement suggestions rather than rejection.

Provide details of past claims including date, voyage route, cargo type, cause of loss, and claim amount. Mention corrective measures taken. This helps underwriters assess whether past issues were one-time events or systemic problems.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Jan 2024 - Water damage to electronics shipment Mumbai-Singapore due to container leak, Claim: ₹25 lakhs, Now use waterproof inner packaging

questions.guidance_text: Select all Incoterms you use in trade contracts. These determine when cargo risk transfers between buyer and seller, affecting who needs insurance. FOB/FCA terms mean you need coverage from warehouse to port, while CIF/CIP includes full transit.

Check if your cargo needs special storage like refrigeration, humidity control, or special handling. Temperature-sensitive goods, pharmaceuticals, and perishables need specific coverage clauses and may have higher premiums.

Transhipment means cargo is transferred between vessels/vehicles during transit. This increases handling risk and potential for damage or delay. Direct shipments generally have lower risk than those with multiple transhipments.

Upload your current or recently expired marine policy copy in PDF format. This helps insurers understand your existing coverage and offer matching or better terms. Include all endorsements and clauses for complete review.

Upload an Excel/PDF showing your last 12 months' shipment pattern with values, routes, and frequencies. This data helps insurers understand your risk profile and offer appropriate rates based on actual shipping patterns.

Enter your 15-character GSTIN for tax compliance and invoice generation. Marine insurance premiums attract 18% GST. For imports, insurance premium is considered for customs duty calculation, making proper GST documentation important.

Enter your 10-digit Import Export Code issued by DGFT if you're an importer/exporter. This validates your international trade credentials. While optional for insurance, it helps establish your business authenticity for marine coverage.

questions.question_text: Any Special Requirements or Additional Information?
questions.guidance_text: Mention any unique aspects of your cargo operations, special coverage needs, or specific clauses required by your buyers/banks. Include information about seasonal variations in shipment volumes or any upcoming changes in trade patterns.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Need 48-hour claim settlement clause for letter of credit requirements, Peak season October-March with 3x normal volume
